skills.name: Recognise that the diameter is twice the radius

explanations.A: This is a radius. It is a straight line from the centre to the circumference of the circle.
explanations.B: This is a diameter, not a radius.
explanations.C: This is a tangent, not a radius.
explanations.D: This is a chord, not a radius.

explanations.A: This is a radius. It is a straight line from the centre to the circumference of the circle.
explanations.B: This is a radius. It is a straight line from the centre to the circumference of the circle.
explanations.C: This is a radius. It is a straight line from the centre to the circumference of the circle.
explanations.D: This is NOT a radius. All radii should start at the centre and finish on the circumference.

explanations.A: This is not a radius. The radius is a straight line from the centre to the circumference of a circle.
explanations.B: This is not an arc. An arc is part of the outside edge of the circle.
explanations.C: This is a diameter. It is a straight line from one side of the circle to the other passing, through the centre.
explanations.D: This is not a cicumference. A circumference is the outside edge of a circle.

explanations.A: A 'diagram' refers to the picture as a whole. We want the name of just the line.
explanations.B: This is a diameter. It is a straight line from one side of the circle to the other, passing through the centre.
explanations.C: A 'diagonal' joins opposite corners of straight-sided shapes.
explanations.D: A 'diamond' is a shape with 4 sides. We want the name of this single line.

explanations.A: I think you have halved the radius. Remember the diameter is twice as large as the radius.
explanations.B: This is the circumference if the diameter was 5 cm. We want the diameter.
explanations.C: The diameter is twice as large as the radius. 2 × 5 cm = 10 cm.
explanations.D: i think you have squared the radius. Remember the diameter is twice as large as the radius.

explanations.A: The radius is half of the diameter. 9 cm ÷ 2 = 4.5 cm.
explanations.B: This is the circumference of the circle. We want the radius.
explanations.C: I think you have doubled the diameter. Remember the radius is half of the diameter.
explanations.D: You have taken the square root of the diameter. Remember the radius is half of the diameter.

explanations.A: This is a radius, not the circumference.
explanations.B: This is the circumference. It is the perimeter of a circle.
explanations.C: This is a tangent, not the circumference.
explanations.D: This is a chord, not the circumference.

explanations.A: This distance would be the radius.
explanations.B: This distance would be the diameter.
explanations.C: This is the definition of the circumference.
explanations.D: This would be the area of the circle, not the circumference.

explanations.A: This would be the height if the measurements were both diameters. Remember the radius is only half of the height of each circle.
explanations.B: This would be the answer if 4 cm was a diameter of the smaller circle. Remember that 4 cm is the radius and we need the distance right across the smaller circle to be included in the height.
explanations.C: The height will be the sum of the two diameters. Each diameter is two times the radius. So we have (2 × 6) + (2 × 4) = 12 + 8 = 20 cm.
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied the numbers together. We need to add the height of one circle to the height of the other.

explanations.A: This would be the answer if 3 cm was a diameter of the smaller circle. Remember that 3 cm is the radius and we need the distance right across the smaller circle to be included in the height.
explanations.B: The height of the smaller circle is two times the radius: 2 × 3 = 6 cm. The height of the larger circle is the diameter: 10 cm. Therefore, the total height is 6 + 10 = 16 cm.
explanations.C: This would be the height if the measurements were both radii. One of the measurements is a diameter.
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied the numbers together. We need to add the height of one circle to the height of the other.
